subject: Extracted HTTP response codes to constants

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 1:

I don't see this as a bug. It is enhancement and IMO should be reported as spec-lite for further discussion.

Patch Set 1:

I agree with Abhishek, this should have a spec-lite.  I think this would be a good change ... the discussion has to do with whether the best way to get rid of the "magic numbers" is by adding our own http.py (as swift did) or by using something already defined in one of the libraries we're already using.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

All codes you replaced is presented in httplib for py2/http for py3.
Does it matter to create a separate file for that?

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This patch has been -1ed because it has not been updated in
>=2months. The patch also has either a -1/-2 from a core reviewer or a
-1 from Jenkins.

Please, update/rebase the patch if the lack of updates was actually a
lack of reviews or if you think the patch is still relevant.

**NOTE: This will be abandoned if no update is done in 1 week.**

If this action does not seem accurate, please, ping flaper87 on IRC
and he will gladly revert it. Sorry for the inconvenience and we look
forward to have more contributions from you.

Patch Set 5:

@Henanth: That's a good question about the spec-lite.  I think that since Gabor decided to use six.moves.http_client, which we were already using, as the source of the constants, we don't need a spec-lite anymore.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

I'm good with this change and can move up my review to +2 once you confirm that all the changes you made have coverage in the tests.

Patch Set 5:

@Nikhil: Hey, I think if they had coverage in the tests, they are still covered after this modification. And furthermore, as I didn't changed the status codes in the tests, my change must be valid, according to the tests.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

Gabor, please don't take this -2 as a knock against you--I think you have done quite good work here.  I just have a general code stability question that needs some discussion before this patch is merged.

It's great that Gabor submitted this patch without modifying the tests.  Now we know that at least for the code covered by the tests, no mistakes were made in transcribing integer values for symbolic constants.  (I feel much better about this patch than if Gabor had modified the tests.)

At this point, I wonder if we should ask for a follow-up patch that changes the integer values in the tests for the symbolic constants?  The reasoning is that if the symbolic constants are a superior way to refer to HTTP response codes, then we should be using the symbolic constants everywhere in our code (including in tests) from now on.  (And if we don't think that's the case, then shouldn't we reject this patch?)

Now, there's a possibility that a transcription error could occur in migrating tests integer -> constants.  Am I correct in saying that as long as the test changes are done *before* this patch merges, if a transcription error occurred, a test would fail, and Gabor would be able to detect and fix it?  If so, what's the best way to require this desirable follow-up change?  I'm thinking by making this patch a dependency on the test-change patch?  That way, each patch can be tested independently, i.e., (1) symbolic code with integer tests and (2) integer code with symbolic tests, but they can only be merged together.

One final point.  This kind of change is important in one respect (it's better to be using the symbolic constants) but trivial in another (just doing find & replace).  So I think it would be worthwhile (and not unduly burdensome) to ask for a code coverage report to make sure that all the lines changed are in fact covered by existing tests.  If so, this would be something worth adding to the Glance dev guidelines.

Thoughts?

excellent points, I agree.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

I think that the patch is pretty good.
Moreover, it was done in the safe way: without test modification.
So WF is the following IMO:
1. Merge this patch: our tests are stable so we shouldn't modify integer values to ensure that http codes were applied correctly. If there is no code in HTTP lib then we would get 500. If codes were mapped incorrectly then tests will show it because they are stable.
2. Now we know codes are correct, it is our invariant so we can safely migrate tests to http codes.
Also we can do the opposite: migrate tests first but it is not necessary IMO.

Patch Set 5:

I just want to be clear that my reason for holding a -2 on this is that I'd like to see a follow-up patch proposed that changes the numerals to constants in the tests.  That would complete this change.  I'd like to see it as a different patch from this one for the reasons Kairat and I mention in our comments.

I'm not going to insist on a code coverage report (although that would be nice!), but I think this change is complete only when both patches are ready.

Patch Set 8:

I'd be interested about the reasoning for this change.

It's marked as bugfix, but the bug does not explain why the current behavior would be wrong. The Commit message is covering well what is being done, but not why.

Really not for or against (now as the conserns from Brian are addressed ref testing and doing the changes in two separate patches) just curious why this is important enough to do and to review?

Patch Set 8:

Hey Erno,

This is a really great question, thanks for asking. Although we can't see any behavioral change after this patch, the source code's quality is getting better (since there is no refactoring type issue, this became a bugfix, but it is not a fix strictly speaking as you correctly pointed out). That's the reason why this patch is made. In several places in the code, the http status codes are used as a magic numbers (for a detailed description of this anti-pattern, see https://sourcemaking.com/refactoring/replace-magic-number-with-symbolic-constant). And that makes the code ugly, and less readable, as there are lots of status codes which you don't remember exactly (at least I don't). For example, it is harder do understand and harder to write unit tests, and you can easily make a mistake and expect another status code than you actually want to get (e.g. I'd like to get 414 response code for the too large request, but can't remember exactly or mistype it, and I wait for 415, which would fail until I figure out I've mistyped the code). So in this patch, (hopefully) every occurrence of these kind of magic numbers have been replaced with symbolic constants (following the suggested refactoring: http://refactoring.com/catalog/replaceMagicNumberWithSymbolicConstant.html). After this, the source code is more readable, and instead of reading simple numbers, you can easily read and understand what is the code supposed to do. I hope you got an answer to your question and now see why this change worths the effort.

Patch Set 8:

Hello, 

Lots of modules have noticed what Péter said, and refactored their code in some ways. In Swift, they use a file [1], where they list and define the status codes, or in nova, they use requests library [2].

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/http.py
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filters/trusted_filter.py#L49

In this patchset, six.moves.http_client is used (it was already used in several places in glance).

Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

Péter and Gábor, thanks for the explanation (with references!) about why this is worth doing.  My only reservation had to do with refactoring the tests, and that's been handled properly (in my opinion) by a separate patch.  Let's try to get this merged soon so we don't run into a bunch of merge conflicts.

Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

Each individual change checks out with the correct mapping of code to message, and I didn't see things left out that should have been included.

I like the improvement to readability. 

Due to the large number of files touched and the distribution of changes through the code-base this has the potential to experience code-rot quickly so another vote for more trying to merge soon.
Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1
